newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL palm oil ends with smaller declines.
newsitem.headline: KL palm oil ends with smaller declines.

text.p: Malaysian palm oil prices ended with smaller declines as late covering helped the market recoup earlier losses, traders said. Falls in soyoil weakened prices initially.

News of export data by SGS (M) Sdn Bhd and expectations India will reduce edible oil imports in coming months had no impact on the market. "The news had no impact on the market as people claimed that it was an old story," a dealer said.
India is expected to reduce purchases in the coming months following good oilseed crop arrivals and adequate palm olein stocks, industry officials in India said on Wednesday.

"New crop arrivals are gathering momentum and we have sufficient inventories of imported palm olein," Navinbhai Shah, president of Bombay Oilseeds and Oil Exchange Ltd, told Reuters in India by telephone. "Therefore imports in the coming three to four months will drop substantially," he said.

India imported an average 80,000 to 100,000 tonnes of palm olein per month during September, October and November. In the next three to four months, India will import a maximum of 40,000 to 50,000 tonnes of palm olein per month, Shah said.
Meanwhile, cargo surveyor SGS (M) Sdn Bhd said that November 1-20 palm oil exports were at 462,394 tonnes.
"The SGS export data has no impact on the market as it was within market expectations," a dealer said.
Technically, traders said the support for third month, February futures contract is still pegged at 1,200 ringgit.
At the close, the contract was seven ringgit down at 1,207 ringgit ($479.16) a tonne after trading between the 1,213 and 1,199 ringgit level.
Turnover on the futures market was 1,625 lots against 1,342 on Tuesday.
In the physical market, Nov (south) crude palm oil was offered at 1,205 ringgit after trading from 1,195 to 1,205. Bid for Nov (south) was 1,202.50 ringgit.
Nov (central) was offered at 1,200 against bids 1,187.50 with earlier trades at 1,190 and 1,195.
Dec (south) saw offers at 1,212.50 ringgit and bids at 1,205 and earlier trades were from 1,205 and 1,215, and Dec (central) was at 1,205 against 1,190.
Jan (south) was offered at 1,220 with bids at 1,212.50.
Among refined products, Dec RBD palm oil was offered at $512.50 a tonne FOB Malaysia, and Jan/Feb/March at $512.50.
Dec RBD palm olein saw offers at $557.50 and Jan/Feb/Mar at $550. Dec was traded from $550 to $555.
Dec RBD palm stearin was offered at $377.50 and Dec/Jan palm fatty acid distillate saw sellers at $307.50. -- Tan Lee Lee (603-230-7510) ($1=2.5190 ringgit)
